results.notes: Growing singly in leaf litter near Quercus spp., Carya spp., Fagus grandifolia, Acer spp., Ulmus spp. and Asimina triloba. Cap dry. Gills free. Stem smooth. Volva thick, white and smooth. Spore print pink. Clamps lacking in the pileipellis and the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia lacking. Cheilocystidia smooth and hyaline; mostly utriform but some lageniform or conical. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spore measurements: (5.5) 6.1 – 8.3 (8.8) × (3.8) 4 – 4.7 (5.1) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.8 (1.9); N = 30, Me = 7.1 × 4.4 µm; Qe = 1.6.

Spore measurements: (6.6) 7.1 – 8.9 (10.2) × (4.3) 4.7 – 5.4 (5.7) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 1.77 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 8.1 × 5 µm; Qe = 1.6.
Pileus 6-8 cm high, initially conical cap, then almost flattened, radiated, with thick white plates, smooth stem, with basal bulb, black spore, white gills, then pink / orange and then quickly black.

Code: Bot_1360/2021-DSC06774
Habitat: Light mountain Fagus sylvatica forest, slightly inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect, calcareous, colluvial ground, in half shade, partly protected from direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 560 m (1.850 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.
Substratum: Bare calcareous rock.
Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; right bank of river Soča, above the main road and the river near Matevž farmhouse, Trenta 1, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.
Comment: Verrucaria nigrescens is a very common, circumglobal lichen growing mostly on calcareous rocks. It is common in the Trenta valley too. Its thallus is superficial, not immersed into the rock (endolithic) as with many other Verrucaria species and relatively thick (0.3 – 0.5 mm). From far it looks like a black tar stain frequent on coastal rocks. From close one can see that the thallus is cracked into fine, irregular areoles, which are smaller than 1 mm. In the cracks among them black prothallus can be seen. Some of the areoles show the upper most part of immersed perithecia. When the thallus is wet it looks quite differently. The cracks in the thallus disappear and the perithecia tips look differently than in the dry state.

Camera: Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70 mm/f4

results.notes:
Thallus areolate, thin and gray, appearing to have epinecral layer. Apothecia black. Small ones appearing lecideine, flat with raised black rim concolorous with disc. Larger aps sessile, some becoming convex. Proper margin often more or less even with a gray thalline margin. Micro: Apothecia with consistent algal layer underneath. Exciple composed of elongate hyphae at margin (not paraplect to my eye). Epihymenium brown, hymenium and subhymenium hyaline. Paraphyses with enlarged apical cell, ~4um diam. Thallus cortex very thin, <5um thick, dark, appears to be paraplectenchymatous after K application. Overlain by epinecral layer ~5um thick. Algal layer immediately below cortex, consistent. Conidia, ellipsoid, ~3×1.5 um.

Spores polarilocular, oblong to ellipsoid with tapered ends. Septum measurements ~2-3 micrometers generally. Some spores from one sectioned ap very long, one measured at 26×7 micrometers. A more typical size was 18×7 micrometers.

Chemistry: Thallus cortex K+violet, outer exciple also K+violet. Epihymenium K-.

Collected by Scott Bristow. Growing scattered near Liriodendron tulipifera, Prunus Serotina, Lindera benzoin, Juglans nigra nearby and two small dead Carya sp. Inside of a thicket of Actaea racemosa. Surfaces and context not bruising. Odor of cat urine among fresher specimens with more of a spicy odor in older specimens. Taste somewhat spicy/acrid, almost like raw onions with cat urine (scott’s notes). Gills not marginate. Clamps present in all tissues. Lactifers present in the lamellar trama. Caulocystidia cylindrical to clavate. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline and cylindrical to clavate. Basidia 2-4 sterigmate. Spores angular with 5-6 angles. Spore measurements: (8.9) 9.6 – 11.1 (11.8) × (6.6) 7.6 – 8.8 (8.9) µm, Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.4 (1.5); N = 30, Me = 10.3 × 8.1 µm; Qe = 1.3.

results.notes: Growing scattered in moss and tree debris near Tsuga canadensis, Fagus grandifolia, Betula spp. and Acer spp. Caps glabrous, translucent striate and umbilicate. Young gills white. Gills short-decurrent and not marginate. Clamps absent or at least very rare in the pileipellis and in all lamellar tissues. Pileipellis a cutis. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia present. Cheilocystidia hyaline, smooth, thin-walled and very variable in shape: tibiiform, lecythigorm, lageniform or utriform, with Some cheilocystidia forked or with secondary septa. Cheilocystidia measurements: (23) 31.2 – 55.5 (63.3) × (7.4) 9.2 – 16.3 (17.4) µm, Q = (2) 2.6 – 4.5 (5); N = 30, Me = 40.6 × 11.8 µm; Qe = 3.5. Basidia 2-4 sterigmate, rarely 1-sterigmate. Found growing in little league fields at a county park. Fields are a mix of grass, clover, dandelion and daisies. A few of them dropped brown spore prints, I’m guessing those might’ve been P. Foenisecii and have been discarded. They were refrigerated for nearly 24 hours between time of collection and when I had chance to photograph them and set them up to take spore prints.

Mostly endolithic/chasmolithic, with a small area of rimose, whitish-yellow thallus that rises a bit more out from sand grains. Apothecia lecideine, large, black, many with wavy margins, plane becoming convex. Margins thick and black, persistent. Largest aps approaching ~2mm diam. Micro: hymenium ~80 um, hyaline. Epihymenium blue-black, ~10um. Subhymenium faintly brown, ~80 um thick. Exciple: outer layer similar in color to epihymenium (blue-black), ~8 um thick, over reddish-brown inner layer.

Exciple C-, Medulla K- (as far as I can tell), I- (not turning blue)

Spores hyaline, simple, 8/ascus. 11.6×5.5, 15.7×7.1, 12.6×5.6, 16.0×8.5, 15.5×7.1, 14.5×6.5, 16.0 × 5.3, 15.0×6.0 um

Growing in an irrigated park lawn. I’ve been exercising at this park weekly for the past year or so and until now the only Panaeolus specimens I’ve found have had characteristics matching something like P. Foenisecii. These developed faint blue bruising along the bottom quarter of the stems. The blue was most noticeable during the first half hour after picking after which the stems continued to darken and the blue became obscured. Not sure if the blue will show up in the pictures I took shortly after picking but I have no doubt that it was visible in person. This park is maintained by the same landscaping crew that tends to another park in the area which has yielded numerous black-spored Panaeolus specimens macroscopically similar to these. Odor similar to typical grocery store mushroom.

Been seeing these lately in Cherrywood neighborhood. I found these growing in shade in a few places, especially along a trail and in an unoccupied parcel. I thought it was a Pluteus species at first but the gills are attached, so no, also the spore print came out brown. More likely Straw-colored Fiber Head (Inocybe fastigiata), I believe, than Pungent Fiber Head (Inocybe sororia), as I could’t detect the pungent “green corn” smell.

Habitat: next to a mountain path, grassland with stony walls and scattered trees; former pasture, locally flat terrain, calcareous ground, partly sunny; partly protected from direct rain by a tree canopy, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 550 m (1.800 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near the abandoned farmhouse Skokar, Trenta 2, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Cladonia fimbriata is a common and widespread lichen. It belongs to ‘Cladonia pyxidata’ group of lichens having trumpet like podetia when not sterile. There are several members of this group not always easy to be determined to species level. They usually have very similar, small ground (primary) squamules. The size, shape, surface of podetia and color of eventually present apothecia or pycnidia are important distinguishing field characters, chemical tests help a lot in confirmation of determinations. Cladonia fimbriata has slender, stout podetia, with relatively shallow cups (abruptly joined to long stalks in mature podetia) with mostly even margins except when fertile having apothecia or pycnidia (in the form of small brown dots – see Fig. 14). Their surface is allover covered by very small, farinose soredia and sometimes with relatively few, if any, small secondary squamules.

Camera: Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

Patch of small fruit bodies on a sloping lawn with planted hornbeam. The lawn is between two buildings; total area less than 1200 square feet. I have found several types of mushrooms in this spot… at least 3 species of Hebeloma (verified by Henry Beker), Cortinarius, Russula, and the Inocybacese. At first I thought these represented a species of Hebeloma. But, the spores are small and covered in warts.
Clavate structures found in mount of gill material are likely basidia/basidioles, although a few look like cystidia.
Two BLAST matches for the ITS include “Cortinarius aff. vernus” and “Cortinarius suberythrinus”. These are similar taxa each housed in what the Quebec Cortinarius study calls “Section Verni”. Other close matches with “Cortinarius vernus” ITS come from a private data bank.

results.notes: Growing in a friend‘s yard in Boise.
Growing on damp soil. Spores smooth, elliptical, non-guttulate, 19.5-21.8 × 10.6-12.3. Paraphyses unbranched, swollen at tips, 4-7 microns wide. Microscopy in lugols and koh
cf. On decorticated wood near a creek. Spores 15.7-23.8 × 4.5-5.4

Seems close to V. flavovirens but MO won’t let me propose that name

On wet wood in creek, apothecia ~2mm. Asci 6-8.5 μm wide, no reaction in Iodine (pic 5 in lugols). Longest spores I could find are about 150 μm long. Many spores measured much shorter, around 50-80 μm, but maybe this is due to disarticulation into part spores (which is mentioned in the literature for V. flavovirens.). Paraphyses both singular and branched.
On saturated, probably deciduous wood in a creek. Microscopy in lugols. Spores 18.4-20 × 4.4-5.6. Asci 8 spored, roughly 100-110 × 10-12.

Thallus gray-brown, matte, areolate, with tall areoles that are fairly blocky. Larger areoles ~1mm diam. Apothecia few, black, immersed, some with a raised thalline rim. Pycnidia abundant, frequently with thick thalline rim also. Thin black hypothallus present around margins. Largest apothecia ~0.6 mm diam Micro: Hymenium ~145 um tall (in 2 other measured aps got closer to 110, but less certain about those measurements), hyaline, subhymenium at deepest point ~85 um, slightly brownish. Conidia 8, 13, 12, 11, 12,10,13 um long.

Update 5/18/21: Smaller ap: hymenium measured ~110 um. Paraphyses moniliform, with upper ~4 cells subglobose, apical cell: 4.5-5.5 um (2 measured).

Spores: large, ovoid, hyaline, 8/ascus: 22×13, 23×12, 24×13, 22×14, 29×15, 22×13 micrometers.

Chemistry: Thallus tissue VERY strongly K+R norstictic acid

Habitat: mixed woods in a damp bottomland. Two clusters growing in root crevices at the base of a living Acer rubrum
Cup: diameters to 28 mm, bell-shaped to broadly convex, smooth, dry with some radial splitting, pale brown. Margin incurved, not striate, fringed with minute brown hairs in one specimen
Gills: free or nearly so, crowded, multiple tiers of lamellulae, reddish brown with paler and distinctly serrate edges
Stipe: length to 58 mm by 5 mm at the apex expanding downward to 7 mm, even or expanding downward, pruinose in the upper half, no obvious fibrils below, whitish, no blue or yellow areas, fibrous, hollowing. No partial veil
Flesh: brittle cap and gills, stringy and tough in the stipe
Odor and taste: not distinctive
Spore print: pink pink

Growing gregariously on a dead, fallen Phytolacca americana stem. Basidiocarps attached by a central point on the pileus. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia absent or rare.
